articles.headline: Weighing Race and Hate in a Mississippi Killing
articles.snippet: A homicide has alternately been called premeditated racial violence or an act of teenage stupidity.
articles.abstract: A homicide has alternately been called premeditated racial violence or an act of teenage stupidity.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — No one disputes that James Craig Anderson, a middle-aged black family man with a quick wit and a demanding sense of style, was robbed, beaten and then run over by a group of white teenagers in a motel parking lot early one morning in June.

articles.headline: The Scramble for Access to Libya’s Oil Wealth Begins
articles.snippet: Britain’s BP, Italy’s Eni, France’s Total and Austria’s OMV stand to gain the most once the conflict ends. But it is unclear whether a rebel government would honor contracts struck by the Qaddafi regime.
articles.abstract: Britain’s BP, Italy’s Eni, France’s Total and Austria’s OMV stand to gain the most once the conflict ends. But it is unclear whether a rebel government would honor contracts struck by the Qaddafi regime.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The fighting is not yet over in Tripoli, but the scramble to secure access to Libya’s oil wealth has already begun.

articles.headline: On Food Safety, a Long List but Little Money
articles.snippet: The Food and Drug Administration is taking on an expanded mission when regulators have little hope for more funding and may even see their budgets cut.
articles.abstract: The Food and Drug Administration is taking on an expanded mission when regulators have little hope for more funding and may even see their budgets cut.
articles.lead_paragraph: This summer there has been a drumbeat of food-related illnesses. Strawberries containing E. coli killed one person in Oregon and sickened at least nine others. Ground turkey contaminated with salmonella poisoned more than 100 people nationwide, with one dead, and prompted one of the largest meat recalls ever. Imported papayas tainted with salmonella sickened at least 99. Sprouts grown in Idaho were linked to salmonella illnesses in five states.

articles.headline: Hip Implant Complaints Surge, Even as the Dangers Are Studied
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. received more than 5,000 reports since January about several artificial hip devices, more than it received about those devices in the last four years.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. received more than 5,000 reports since January about several artificial hip devices, more than it received about those devices in the last four years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government has received a surge in complaints in recent months about failed hip replacements, suggesting that serious problems persist with some types of artificial hips even as researchers scramble to evaluate the health dangers.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Janet Roberts

articles.headline: After Uprising, Rebels Face a Struggle for Unity
articles.snippet: The character of the anti-Qaddafi movement is facing its first real test: Can they build a new government of unity, or will their own internal rivalries mean divisions in the new Libya?
articles.abstract: The character of the anti-Qaddafi movement is facing its first real test: Can they build a new government of unity, or will their own internal rivalries mean divisions in the new Libya?
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — With rebels on the verge of ending Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s long reign, the character of their movement is facing its first real test: Can they build a new government of unity and reconciliation, or will their own internal rivalries mean divisions in the new Libya?
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Qaddafi Defiant After Rebel Takeover
articles.snippet: Fighting continued, with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi nowhere in sight.
articles.abstract: Fighting continued, with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi nowhere in sight.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Backed by NATO airstrikes and seasoned reinforcements, rebel fighters crashed through the gates of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s fortresslike compound Tuesday, running madly across its sprawling lawns, ransacking its barracks for weapons and carting off mementos of his 42-year dictatorship.
